title: 104_hr1219
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Discretionary Spending Reduction and Control Act of 1995". It includes discretionary spending limits. The "Discretionary Spending Reduction and Control Act of 1995" amends the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 by setting new budget authority and outlay limits for fiscal years 1996 to 1999 in the discretionary category. The "Discretionary Spending Reduction and Control Act of 1995" sets new budget authority and outlay limits for fiscal years 1999 and 2000 in the discretionary category. Amendments are made to the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 to reflect these changes. The Budget Act of 1974 is amended to update fiscal years from 1995 to 2000. Section 607 is also amended to reflect the years 1995 to 2000. Sequestration amounts for the Crime Trust Fund are specified for fiscal years 1996, 1997, and 1998. The Budget Act of 1974 is amended to update fiscal years from 1995 to 2000, with specified sequestration amounts for the Crime Trust Fund for fiscal years 1996, 1997, and 1998. Appropriations for fiscal years 1998, 1999, and 2000 are outlined, with the repeal of certain sentences from the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994. SEC. 3. GENERAL STATEMENT AND DEFINITIONS. Section 250(b) of the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 is amended to enforce deficit reduction through discretionary spending limits and pay-as-you-go requirements for fiscal years 1995 through 2000. Definitions in Section 250(c) are updated, including the term 'category' referring to all discretionary appropriations and 'budgetary resources' encompassing various financial elements. In amending the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985, changes are made to enforce deficit reduction through spending limits and pay-as-you-go requirements for fiscal years 1995 through 2000. This includes updating definitions such as 'category' and 'budgetary resources'. SEC. 4. ENFORCING DISCRETIONARY SPENDING LIMITS. Section 251 of the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 is amended to update the years mentioned in various subsections from 1991-1998 to 1995-2000. This includes adjustments to discretionary spending limits for the specified years. The Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 is amended to update years from 1991-1998 to 1995-2000. This includes adjustments to discretionary spending limits for fiscal years 1995-2000. SEC. 5. ENFORCING PAY-AS-YOU-GO. Amendments are made to the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985, updating years from 1991-1998 to 1995-2000 in various subsections. 

SEC. 6. REPORTS AND ORDERS. Section 254 of the Act is also amended to change the year references from 1998 to 2000 in subsections.

SEC. 7. TECHNICAL CORRECTION. SEC. 7. TECHNICAL CORRECTION. Repeals Section 258 of the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985. SEC. 8. EFFECTIVE DATE. Amends expiration dates in Sections 275(b) and 14002(c)(3) of related acts. SEC. 9. SPECIAL RULE ON INTERRELATIONSHIP BETWEEN CHANGES IN DISCRETIONARY SPENDING LIMITS AND PAY-AS-YOU-GO REQUIREMENTS. Section 252 of the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 is amended to include a special rule on the interrelationship between sections 251 and 252. This rule states that when a reconciliation Act decreases discretionary spending limits and offsets an increase in direct spending or decrease in receipts, the reduction in receipts or increase in outlays shall not be reflected in estimates. The term 'composite spendout rate' is defined as a computational relationship between outlays and new budget. The computational relationship between outlays and new budget authority is detailed in the text, with specific percentages allocated for each year. Additionally, a reconciliation Act is defined as a bill enacted into law. Amendments to the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 are also outlined, including the addition of a new paragraph related to the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985. The Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 allows for deficit increases to be offset by reductions in discretionary outlays. Changes in direct spending and receipts from certain acts are not reflected in estimates under the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985. Reducing the limit on discretionary outlays for fiscal years 1999 and 2000 is measured from the limit for fiscal year 1998. In the OMB final sequestration report for fiscal year 1996... In the OMB final sequestration report for fiscal year 1996, adjustments required by section 251(b)(2) after the preview report shall be made to discretionary spending limits. Statutory changes in discretionary spending limits by certain acts shall also be made to those limits.
